barath amarnath wrote:
> Hi All,
> Our system having module named Doc Management. In this
> module, the one class is generating filepath and
> filename as per STRING pattern
> (such as
> c:\temp\[date]\[time]\dynamicallygeneratedfilename
> c:\temp\[date][time]\randomnumber\dynamicallygeneratedfilename
> 
> I am in the process of writing test cases for the
> above dynamically generated file path and name.
> 
> If any of you give some tips or ideas how to test this
> functionality, it will be very useful to me.

A few things:

1. Test generating the filename on its own, without creating any actual 
files on disk.

2. Separate the random number generator or clock from creating the 
filename. The method that creates the filename should take a random 
number generator or clock as a parameter.

The reason for #1 is pretty obvious. The reason for #2 is to make it 
possible to test creating the filename without having to know what 
random number comes next.

Here's the first test I'd write, based on the system time:

testSystemTimeBasedFilename {
     Clock fakeClock = new StoppedClock(2004, 5, 26, 17, 25, 0);

     assertEquals(
         new File("c:/temp/20040526/172500/myFileName").getAbsolutePath(),
         new File(FileUtil.generateFileName(fakeClock)).getAbsolutePath());
}

where...

interface Clock {
     long getTime();
}

and...

class StoppedClock implements Clock {
     StoppedClock(int year, int month, ...) {}

     long getTime() { return ...; }
}

and finally...

class SystemClock implements Clock {
     long getTime() {
         return System.currentTimeMillis();
     }
}

so that in production....

String timeBasedFileName = FileUtil.generateFileName(new SystemClock());

NOTE: SystemClock could be a Singleton if you like.

You can do something similar with java.util.Random, wrapping it in some 
RandomNumberGenerator interface.

The idea is to easily replace unrepeatable behavior (system clock, 
random numbers) with repeatable behavior (fake versions of the clock or 
a random number generator). Use the fake stuff to make testing easier, 
then use the real stuff in production.

Enjoy.
